titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Nasher Museum of Art records, 1947-2018, bulk 1990s-2018 UA.07.10.0002
titlestmt.author: Tracy M. Jackson

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-10-23 08:48:09 -0400.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Nasher Museum of Art at Duke University

did.abstract: The Nasher Museum, founded as the Duke University Museum of Art in 1969, opened in its current building in 2005. The museum's collection focuses on works by diverse artists, European medieval art, European and American paintings, Outsider art, classical antiquities, African art, and ancient American art. The Nasher Museum of Art records include materials related to exhibits and events at the Nasher as well as the planning, construction, and opening of the museum building.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials have been arranged by accession. Materials have been consolidated into fewer boxes but have not otherwise been arranged. Folder and item titles are largely original.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Nasher Museum was founded as the Duke University Museum of Art in 1969, in a renovated science building on the University's East Campus. In 1998, Duke alumnus Raymond D. Nasher donated funds to support construction of a new art museum, and it was subsequently named for him. Construction began in 2000 on the new building, designed by Rafael Violy, and the Nasher Museum opened officially in 2005.

The museum's permanent collection focuses on works by diverse artists, particularly artists of African descent, as well as European medieval art, European and American paintings, Outsider art, classical antiquities, African art, and ancient American art. The Nasher also presents rotating exhibitions that frequently travel around the United States and internationally. Major traveling exhibitions have included El Greco to Vel√°zquez: Art during the Reign of Philip III (named one of Time magazine's top 10 shows of 2008) and Southern Accent: Seeking the American South in Contemporary Art (2016-17).

The Director of the Nasher when it opened in 2005 was Kimberly Rorschach, who served in that role from 2004 to 2012. Sarah Schroth served as Interim Director 2012-2013 before serving as Director 2012-2020. Trevor Schoonmaker took over as Director in summer 2020.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Access restricted. For a period of twenty-five years from the origin of the material, permission in writing from the office of origin and the University Archivist is required for use of administrative records. After twenty-five years, records that have been processed may be consulted with the permission of the University Archivist. Contact Research Services for more information.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Copyright for official university records is held by Duke University; all other copyright is retained by the authors of items in these papers, or their descendants, as stipulated by United States copyright law.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Nasher Museum of Art records were received by the Duke University Archives as a series of transfers in 2019 and 2020.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Nasher Museum of Art records, Duke University Archives, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Tracy M. Jackson, October 2020.
Materials have not been reviewed or arranged beyond consolidating boxes; inventories were provided and most folder titles are original.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Duke Museum of Art records, UA.07.10.0001, Duke University Archives.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Nasher Museum of Art records include materials related to exhibits and events at the Nasher as well as the planning, construction, and opening of the museum building. Included are brochures, programs, clippings and publications, photographs, event planning materials, newsletters, correspondence, and other materials.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access note. Collection contains electronic records that must be requested and accessed in our reading room. Contact Research Services with questions.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access note. Collection contains fragile audiovisual/photographic/electronic formats that may need to be reformatted before use. Contact Research Services for access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Events documented include 2003 Alumni event in Dallas, the 2005 and 2010 Annual Meeting of the Nasher Museum Friends Board, 2005 Director's Reception, staff going away party, and 2005 Taste of Durham celebration. Digital photographs in JPEG and Adobe PSD formats.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes images from the exhibits The Forest: Politics, Poetics, and Practice; The Record: Contemporary Art and Vinyl; Between Past and Future: New Photography and Video from China; and Sacred Beauty: Medieval and Renaissance Illuminated Manuscripts from the Collection of Robert J. Parsons. For the exhibit Beyond Beauty: Photographs from the Duke University Special Collections Library, caption text is included with images. Also included are sculpture installation photographs of works by Mark Di Survero, Anthony Caro, Alain Kirili, and unidentified artists. Also included are photographs from an unidentified exhibit catalogue and unidentified exhibit. Digital images in JPEG and TIFF formats. Document files in MS Word and PowerPoint formats.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Also included are sculpture installation photographs of works by Mark Di Survero, Anthony Caro, Alain Kirili, and unidentified artists. Also included are photographs from an unidentified exhibit catalogue and unidentified exhibit. Digital images in JPEG and TIFF formats. Document files in MS Word and PowerPoint formats.

did.unittitle: The State of Things with Frank Stasio episode featuring Irwin Kremen

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Audio recording of Public Radio broadcast episode featuring Irwin Kremen, promoting his exhibit Beyond Black Mountain, 1966-2006. Recordings in WAV format.
